definition: to go out/to come out/to occur/to produce/to go beyond/to rise/to put forth/to happen/(used after a verb to indicate an outward direction or a positive result)/classifier for dramas, plays, operas etc
variant of 出[chu1] (classifier for plays or chapters of classical novels)

sentences.english: Grant wasted no time. He quickly sent troops to fight the Confederate force blocking the Tennessee River.
sentences.chinese: 格兰特马不停蹄，迅速出兵，阻南军于田纳西州河畔。

sentences.english: One year, the State of Qin sent troops to attack Zhao and surrounded the capital of Handan.
sentences.chinese: 有一年，秦国出兵攻打赵国，并已经包围了都城邯郸。

sentences.english: Yuan Shao dispatched troops to occupy most of Dongjun after a long time siege.
sentences.chinese: 袁绍出兵经长期围攻重新占据东郡大部。

sentences.english: When the nobles rebelled , the king battled them .
sentences.chinese: 当贵族谋反时，国王便出兵打他们。

sentences.english: This time the question was whether China would join the fighting on the North Korean side.
sentences.chinese: 这一次，问题是中国是否会出兵与北朝鲜并肩战斗。

sentences.english: So when third sedition occurred in his kingdom in three years, he sent help to Rome to aid him in suppressing it.
sentences.chinese: 当埃及发生叛乱时，他曾派人向罗马求助出兵平乱。

sentences.english: In 1927, Tanaka Giichi sent troops to Shandong, and then held the Eastern Conference.
sentences.chinese: 1927年田中义一出兵山东，后召开东方会议。

sentences.english: TheUK currently contributes the second largest number of troops to theAfghan mission.
sentences.chinese: 英国目前是阿富汗任务的第二大出兵国。

definition: to dispatch an army/to send troops
to reinforce/to increase troop numbers/reinforcements/extra troops
to put down a revolt/to pacify a rebellion
to go on a punitive expedition
to take to the field oneself (of emperor)/to take part in person in an expedition
to suppress by armed force/to send a punitive expedition against/to crusade against
